conclusion: Understanding the problem involves analyzing a displacement vs. time graph to find when speed is 5 m/s.
The graph starts at 10 meters at time zero, decreases, crosses zero at about 2 seconds, and reaches -10 meters at 4 seconds.
Speed is the magnitude of velocity; find when the absolute value of velocity is 5 m/s.
The slope of the tangent on a displacement-time graph gives the velocity.
Find points where the slope of the tangent is Â±5 to determine when speed is 5 m/s.
The curve is decreasing throughout 4 seconds, with a faster decrease after t=2 s.
Estimate tangent slopes at different points to find where slope is -5 m/s or 5 m/s.
At t=0 s, the displacement is 10 m, and the initial slope is maybe -3 or -4 m/s.
At t=1 s, the displacement is around 5 m, and the tangent might have a slope of -5 m/s.
At t=3 s, the displacement is around -5 m, and the tangent seems steeper, maybe -7 or -8 m/s.
At t=2 s, the displacement is 0 m, and the tangent seems almost vertical.
The problem mentions 'key step illustration' with tangent lines at specific points.
In the first image, at t=1 s, a tangent line is drawn; in the second image, at t=3 s, another tangent line is drawn.
At t=1 s, the tangent line has a slope of about -5 m/s, so speed is 5 m/s.
At t=3 s, the tangent line has a slope of about -7 m/s, so speed is 7 m/s.
Check for another point where speed is 5 m/s between t=2 s and t=3 s.
At t=2 s, displacement is 0 m, and the tangent is very steep, maybe around -9 m/s.
At t=1.5 s, the tangent might be around -5 m/s again.
Calculate average velocity between t=1 s and t=3 s as -5 m/s.
Confirm instantaneous velocity at t=1 s matches speed of 5 m/s.
